text: recently I have received so many
requests from you guys for when my new
Moya and I haven't realized how popular
it has become until last night when I
had a ride around the city so many
stores has been pop up just selling this
one dish so I've decided to drop in one
to find out why many people were queuing
to order takeaway and the selling team
were working on full capacity to fulfill
them the dish is pretty simple with the
Vietnamese baguette brushed with some
butter a special sauce and then grilled
over charcoal till golden brown then
they cut a roll off press it flat cut
into bite-sized pieces and then top with
a scallion oi some poor flaws and
Vietnamese sausages it looks really
simple but I was really amazed by the
simplicity and deliciousness
what a wonderful snack whoever thought
of this must be a genius and nothing
could make me happier than having this
with some bubble tea at the sides so
let's try making it at home let's begin
to make the satay sauce you're gonna
need 1 shallot 2 cloves of garlic 2
large Chili Peppers or jalapenos 1 stalk
of lemongrass 2 sprigs of spring onion
and a tablespoon of dry streams and a
tablespoon of chili flakes firstly you
want to mix the chili flakes with a
tablespoon of hot water so it will not
burn when we stir fry soak the dry
streams in warm water to soften cut away
and save the white part of green onion
and jump up the green part then cut the
white part spring onion the shallots the
garlic lemongrass and chili into smaller
pieces and then combine everything into
a food processor to blitz
so a disciplined cry streams and flames
heat four tablespoons of vegetable right
in a pen when it's nice and hot pour
half of it over the green onion bowl and
then you have the scallion Roy or Mahan
now after the initial actually
lemongrass paste into the farro and
saute for about two to three minutes
until it's gets really aromatic control
your heat because you really don't want
to burn this oh my god it smells so good
then add the chili flakes and simmer on
low for about three to five minutes
stirring constantly then transfer this
satay into a bowl now in a small
saucepan combine half a cup of this
sauce with 75 grams sugar and stir on
low heat until the sugar is completely
dissolved and let it bubble for two to
three minutes on low heat transfer to a
bowl and let cool and half of the satay
that we've made and a tablespoon of hot
sauce or a sriracha let the sauce kundo
completely and if you chill in the
fridge overnight it will get a lot
thicker now cut some sausages into
sticks and then prepare some melted
butter and pop floss of course you need
a Vietnamese baguette for this it's very
fluffy and airy you can roll it flat
with a rolling pin brush with some
butter until shiny and then the
stickiest spicy sauce what that looks
really sexy you can grill this over
charcoal or using an infrared stove like
I do or you can also put it in the oven
at 200 degrees Celsius for just about
four to five minutes that's it oh my god
it smells so good at the butter in the
sad day
you can use kitchen shears to cut into
smaller pieces and add a lot of scallion
Roy some pop flaws and sausage and don't
forget to drizzle on top the mayonnaise
and a little bit more of chili sauce oh
my god I cannot wait the leftover sauce
if any can be kept in the fridge and you
can use it to make a hole or the core it
smells amazing the bagasse is crispy and
it's absorbed their flavorful savory
spicy from this delicious sauce you have
to give a try to know what I mean if you
do please share photo on instagram with
hashtag hell and recipes thank you for
watching bye bye
